content.body:
Yoav Weiss: For Mozilla Developer Network docs, can you please confirm that the device client hints that disappeared from the spec after https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-client-hints-06 are deprecated (were removed permanently from the spec and have not been moved elsewhere)? 

Specifically, Content-DPR, DPR, Viewport-Width, Width
content.formatted_body:
Yoav Weiss: For Mozilla Developer Network docs, can you please confirm that the device client hints that disappeared from the spec after https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-client-hints-06 are deprecated (were removed permanently from the spec and have not been moved elsewhere)?

Specifically, Content-DPR, DPR, Viewport-Width, Width

content.body: Hamish Willee: It was removed from the ID to be moved to other specs. See https://wicg.github.io/responsive-image-client-hints/ for the current spec for image-related client hints
content.formatted_body: Hamish Willee: It was removed from the ID to be moved to other specs. See https://wicg.github.io/responsive-image-client-hints/ for the current spec for image-related client hints

content.body: This is the PR that removed the features: https://github.com/httpwg/http-extensions/pull/775
@jakea:matrix.org Hey, I looked into the GC issue. I’ll comment on the crbug tomorrow, but I think it turns out to be pretty subtle, and may have also exposed a bug in MutationObserver
content.formatted_body: @jakea:matrix.org Hey, I looked into the GC issue. I’ll comment on the crbug tomorrow, but I think it turns out to be pretty subtle, and may have also exposed a bug in MutationObserver

content.body:
timothygu: Thanks very much! Can you confirm the summary of the changes:
- Width, Viewport-Width, DPR were deprecated and replaced by same haders with Sec-CH- prefix (e.g. Sec-CH-DPR)
- New header Sec-CH-Viewport-Height
- Removal of Content-DPR altogether?

As a slight aside, one of the examples in the spec appears to omit the SEC- prefix in the Accept-CH - is that OK?:
Accept-CH: CH-DPR, CH-Width
content.formatted_body:
timothygu: Thanks very much! Can you confirm the summary of the changes:

  • Width, Viewport-Width, DPR were deprecated and replaced by same haders with Sec-CH- prefix (e.g. Sec-CH-DPR)
  • New header Sec-CH-Viewport-Height
  • Removal of Content-DPR altogether?

As a slight aside, one of the examples in the spec appears to omit the SEC- prefix in the Accept-CH - is that OK?:
Accept-CH: CH-DPR, CH-Width

content.body: @hamishwillee:matrix.org I don’t have any info beyond the links I sent, but it’s worth going through the PRs to that spec to understand historical changes. Re the example omission, you could file an issue on GitHub for clarification
content.formatted_body: @hamishwillee:matrix.org I don’t have any info beyond the links I sent, but it’s worth going through the PRs to that spec to understand historical changes. Re the example omission, you could file an issue on GitHub for clarification

content.body:
> <@timothygu:matrix.org> @jakea:matrix.org Hey, I looked into the GC issue. I’ll comment on the crbug tomorrow, but I think it turns out to be pretty subtle, and may have also exposed a bug in MutationObserver

Ohh, keen to know more
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @timothygu:matrix.org
@jakea:matrix.org Hey, I looked into the GC issue. I’ll comment on the crbug tomorrow, but I think it turns out to be pretty subtle, and may have also exposed a bug in MutationObserver
Ohh, keen to know more

content.body: Hamish Willee: The old header names are indeed deprecated in spec, but the Chromium implementation needs to catch up
content.formatted_body: Hamish Willee: The old header names are indeed deprecated in spec, but the Chromium implementation needs to catch up

content.body: Content-DPR was somewhat replaced by https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/5574
(but wasn't removed from Chromium AFAIK)
Eric Portis (not in here, for some reason) is editing that spec. I believe PRs and corrections would be appreciated
Thanks @yoa

* Thanks Yoav Weiss - really helpful. I've created an issue for the problem case. I'm thinking this might be a little early to document for MDN, but am checking internally. Either way will link the old docs to the new spec in some way so that we have this information when ready to start.
content.formatted_body: * Thanks Yoav Weiss - really helpful. I've created an issue for the problem case. I'm thinking this might be a little early to document for MDN, but am checking internally. Either way will link the old docs to the new spec in some way so that we have this information when ready to start.

m.new_content.body: Thanks Yoav Weiss - really helpful. I've created an issue for the problem case. I'm thinking this might be a little early to document for MDN, but am checking internally. Either way will link the old docs to the new spec in some way so that we have this information when ready to start.

I'm thinking this might be a little early to document for MDN, but am checking internally. Either way will link the old docs to the new spec in some way so that we have this information when ready to start.

content.body: sideshowbarker: what would be a short term fix for https://github.com/whatwg/encoding/issues/261?
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: what would be a short term fix for https://github.com/whatwg/encoding/issues/261?

content.body:
> <@annevk:mozilla.org> sideshowbarker: what would be a short term fix for https://github.com/whatwg/encoding/issues/261?

I can add a filter to our script, to cause those messages to be suppressed
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:mozilla.org
sideshowbarker: what would be a short term fix for https://github.com/whatwg/encoding/issues/261?
I can add a filter to our script, to cause those messages to be suppressed

content.body: sideshowbarker: yeah, I guess I can do that too
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: yeah, I guess I can do that too

content.body:
> <@annevk:mozilla.org> sideshowbarker: yeah, I guess I can do that too

Yeah, maybe give it a try. If it doesn't work for some reason, I can look at it later
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:mozilla.org
sideshowbarker: yeah, I guess I can do that too
Yeah, maybe give it a try. If it doesn't work for some reason, I can look at it later

content.body: sideshowbarker: I added `.*Possible misuse of “aria-label”. (If you disagree with this warning, file an issue report or send e-mail to www-validator@w3.org.).*` to .htmlcheckerfilter and it does not appear to work
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: I added .*Possible misuse of “aria-label”. (If you disagree with this warning, file an issue report or send e-mail to www-validator@w3.org.).* to .htmlcheckerfilter and it does not appear to work

content.body: Ok, I'll take a look at it in a bit
annevk: so yeah it was the parens
content.formatted_body: annevk: so yeah it was the parens

content.body: since it’s a regex, the parens need to be escaped
for the for record, alternately it can just be `.*Possible misuse of “aria-label”.*`
content.formatted_body: for the for record, alternately it can just be .*Possible misuse of “aria-label”.*

content.body: that is, it can match on just some portion of the message
it’s not strictly necessary to include the whole message
sideshowbarker: thanks, good to know for next time; perhaps we should document that somewhere
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: thanks, good to know for next time; perhaps we should document that somewhere

content.body: I have the general upstream documentation for the feature at https://github.com/validator/validator/wiki/Message-filtering
but that doesn’t provide enough detail I guess
it needs some examples
but anyway it’s wiki, so anybody can make changes to it
sideshowbarker: how quick is the filtering of warnings? I do get the impression the build times for Encoding are even worse now
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: how quick is the filtering of warnings? I do get the impression the build times for Encoding are even worse now

content.body: I don't think the filtering adds any noticeable time to a build
That Encoding build has just always taken a long time, as far as I can recall
annevk: https://github.com/whatwg/encoding/issues/261 should be closed now
content.formatted_body: annevk: https://github.com/whatwg/encoding/issues/261 should be closed now

content.body: Andreu Botella (he/they): should it? I think we still need to decide how to resolve that warning
content.formatted_body: Andreu Botella (he/they): should it? I think we still need to decide how to resolve that warning

content.body: rereads the log
oh, right

annevk: so as far the performance effects from the filtering of warnings: when I test locally with filtering on, it takes 4m16.409s to check all the Encoding documents — but when when test without the filtering, it takes 9m31.435s
content.formatted_body: annevk: so as far the performance effects from the filtering of warnings: when I test locally with filtering on, it takes 4m16.409s to check all the Encoding documents — but when when test without the filtering, it takes 9m31.435s

content.body: that is, with the filtering on, it’s not slower but actually more than twice as fast

well that kind of makes sense to me intuitively, because without the filtering there are literally thousands of warnings getting dumped out — and there’s a system I/O cost to emitting all those, and prior to that, some internal cost to formatting them all for output
yeah agreed, I guess what I'm wondering if what the cost for hitting the warning is, even if the warning ends up getting filtered
because we hit it a lot
yeah

well, given that the accessibility people have said that putting aria-label on td elements is not good for AT users in current AT, it seems like rightly what we should be doing is, not putting aria-label on all those td elements
sideshowbarker: it would be good to know what to do instead though
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: it would be good to know what to do instead though

content.body: it seems like one possibility is that there actually isn’t anything to do instead
that is, we drop the attributes and don’t replace them with anything else
there are some limitations in AT that it’s not within our domain knowledge to figure out how to overcome
there are people whose full-time occupation is figuring out how to solve problems like this for paying customers
I seem to recall having Cc’ed somebody on that issue, but we didn’t get any specific suggestions from them about how to fix it
Wait, what, you're saving 4 minutes just not outputting warnings? Terminals must surely allow output at at least 1-10Mb/s, which suggests like 240Mb-2.4Gb of output, if that was the main bottleneck.
jgraham: we're talking about a lot of non-conforming table cells here, so it wouldn't surprise me
content.formatted_body: jgraham: we're talking about a lot of non-conforming table cells here, so it wouldn't surprise me

content.body: sideshowbarker:  there is plenty more info wrt table a11y in this section for the `gridcell` role https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.1/#gridcell
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: there is plenty more info wrt table a11y in this section for the gridcell role https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.1/#gridcell

content.body: depending on the table, `role="rowheader"` and `scope="row"` may be necessary too
content.formatted_body: depending on the table, role="rowheader" and scope="row" may be necessary too

content.body: government websites are mandated by law to provide AT support nowadays
well, at least there were several laws passed in the US about it
The question is how to convey the type-identifying background color in table such as https://encoding.spec.whatwg.org/windows-1252.html

240Mb of warnings would be > 3kB of output per BMP character. Not impossible of course, but quite a lot. It's of course also possible that something internally is really slow so the estimate of 1Mb/s of output is high. But it at least feels suspicious when something is _that_ slow.
content.formatted_body: 240Mb of warnings would be > 3kB of output per BMP character. Not impossible of course, but quite a lot. It's of course also possible that something internally is really slow so the estimate of 1Mb/s of output is high. But it at least feels suspicious when something is that slow.

content.body: jgraham: well, but each encoding has a BMP table, plus at least one other table
content.formatted_body: jgraham: well, but each encoding has a BMP table, plus at least one other table

content.body: There might still be something wrong, but there's definitely a lot of output as well

annevk: hmm, you may want to look into `aria-describedby` and move the legend (key) onto the same document https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Roles/Gridcell_role#describing_the_position_of_gridcells_when_the_overall_structure_is_unknown
content.formatted_body: annevk: hmm, you may want to look into aria-describedby and move the legend (key) onto the same document https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Roles/Gridcell_role#describing_the_position_of_gridcells_when_the_overall_structure_is_unknown

content.body: > The `aria-describedby` attributed is not designed to reference descriptions on an external resource—since it is an ID, it must reference an element in the same DOM document.
content.formatted_body: The aria-describedby attributed is not designed to reference descriptions on an external resource—since it is an ID, it must reference an element in the same DOM document.

content.body: But that isn't entirely true either right? The headers do provide information about the cell. They just don't convey this other information that's really a property of the contents of the cell.
> The headers do provide information about the cell.
content.formatted_body: The headers do provide information about the cell.

content.body: that does not appear to be the case

the headers are simply numbers, but i do see that there `aria-label="Two bytes, contiguous"` on each cell, which was probably done seeing as how the key is on another page and the headers don't provide any descriptive info whatsoever afaik
content.formatted_body: the headers are simply numbers, but i do see that there aria-label="Two bytes, contiguous" on each cell, which was probably done seeing as how the key is on another page and the headers don't provide any descriptive info whatsoever afaik

content.body: They are numbers, yes, but in the context of encodings they are highly relevant
oh, okay well it's an interesting problem and that is one of the most funky tables i have ever seen (definition list w/ one item in it per cell) lol
it reminds me a lot of a periodic table of the elements
surely someone has made one of those w/ full a11y support; perhaps that would be a good way to see how it's done
annevk: ohh this one looks promising! it has an `aria-labelledby="sections"` referencing some `id` of an item in the legend http://dylanb.github.io/periodic-aria-roles.html
content.formatted_body: annevk: ohh this one looks promising! it has an aria-labelledby="sections" referencing some id of an item in the legend http://dylanb.github.io/periodic-aria-roles.html

content.body: * annevk: ohh this one looks promising! it has an `aria-labelledby` attribute referencing some `id` of an item in the legend http://dylanb.github.io/periodic-aria-roles.html
content.formatted_body: * annevk: ohh this one looks promising! it has an aria-labelledby attribute referencing some id of an item in the legend http://dylanb.github.io/periodic-aria-roles.html

m.new_content.body: annevk: ohh this one looks promising! it has an `aria-labelledby` attribute referencing some `id` of an item in the legend http://dylanb.github.io/periodic-aria-roles.html
m.new_content.formatted_body: annevk: ohh this one looks promising! it has an aria-labelledby attribute referencing some id of an item in the legend http://dylanb.github.io/periodic-aria-roles.html

content.body: DerekNonGeneric: but that doesn't have meaningful row/column headers
content.formatted_body: DerekNonGeneric: but that doesn't have meaningful row/column headers

content.body: i thought that you could not use headers for some reason?
obviously that would be the best way to do it if you can
well, not sure if the numbers in the current header are what you had in mind
wow, til that there is even `headers` attribute that you can use to specify multiple headers in the event that the table is more complex https://www.davidmacd.com/blog/csun/files/complex-tables.html
content.formatted_body: wow, til that there is even headers attribute that you can use to specify multiple headers in the event that the table is more complex https://www.davidmacd.com/blog/csun/files/complex-tables.html

content.body: that table is missing a lot of things, at the very least you should add `scope="row"` to the `th` that are in the `tbody` element (!)
content.formatted_body: that table is missing a lot of things, at the very least you should add scope="row" to the th that are in the tbody element (!)

content.body: I'm pretty sure that the scope of the headers is correct per the HTML Standard, a bunch of that doesn't have to be explicitly stated

surely the markup is valid, not saying it's not, but w/o specifying the scope as row, i don't think those headers will be describing the data in the row... might also want to check out what the spec says, since it doesn't look like that somehow gets autodetected https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/tables.html#attr-th-scope-row
If you keep reading you'll get to it

is it the part about the `auto` state?

> The auto state makes the header cell apply to a set of cells selected based on context.
content.formatted_body:
is it the part about the auto state?

The auto state makes the header cell apply to a set of cells selected based on context.

content.body:

#jems ?
jgraham:  466MB total, 2,134,130 messages is the output from running the checker on those Encoding files
content.formatted_body: jgraham: 466MB total, 2,134,130 messages is the output from running the checker on those Encoding files

content.body: as unbelievable as that may sound
and that’s basically the same message 2,134,130 times (there are a few other messages it emits that I’m not filtering out locally)
and I think due to the way the code is written, that message string isn’t even getting interned
I guess for the general behavior of the checker, interning or not of messages wouldn’t make any noticeable performance difference in the normal case. But it seems like it would in this case.
When WebIDL says to get a copy of the bytes held by a buffer source, the actual "getting a copy of the bytes" part is not formalized in terms of the ECMAScript spec operations
and so it's not clear if for `[AllowShared] BufferSource`s, that copy should be raw or atomic
content.formatted_body: and so it's not clear if for [AllowShared] BufferSources, that copy should be raw or atomic

content.body: Andreu Botella (he/they): https://github.com/heycam/webidl/pull/987
content.formatted_body: Andreu Botella (he/they): https://github.com/heycam/webidl/pull/987

content.body: I went looking for issues, not PRs 🤦
Domenic: So copies and writes are unordered, and WebIDL doesn't provide anything to make them `SeqCst`?
content.formatted_body: Domenic: So copies and writes are unordered, and WebIDL doesn't provide anything to make them SeqCst?

content.body: @hamishwillee:matrix.org Just replied to your responsive image client hints questions on GH (thanks for the issues!). Your three-bullet summary of the changes looks accurate. I'll be around here going forward, if you have questions about the spec.
